title: 108_hr4211
content: The "Safe Health Care Reporting Act of 2004" amends the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 to change references from "Boards of medical examiners" to "State licensing boards" and expand reporting requirements to include all health care practitioners, not just physicians. The "Safe Health Care Reporting Act of 2004" expands reporting requirements to include all health care practitioners, not just physicians. SEC. 3 mandates reporting of certain professional review actions. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reporting on licensed health care practitioners to State licensing boards. This expands reporting requirements to include all health care practitioners, not just physicians. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reporting on licensed health care practitioners to State licensing boards, including details of adverse actions taken against practitioners for potential violations of Federal or State laws. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reporting adverse actions to State licensing boards, with specific guidelines for reporting under subsection (a)(2) and redesignations of subsections. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reporting adverse actions to State licensing boards and impose civil penalties for non-compliance, with a maximum penalty of $50,000 per violation for health care entities. Additional penalties may be imposed for repeated violations. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reporting adverse actions to State licensing boards and impose civil penalties for non-compliance, with a maximum penalty of $50,000 per violation for health care entities. Additional penalties may be imposed for repeated violations. Civil penalties are addressed in Section 4. Section 425 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to replace "hospital" with "health care entity or agency employing a physician or other licensed health care practitioner" in various subsections. It also requires reporting adverse actions to State licensing boards and imposes civil penalties for non-compliance, with a maximum penalty of $50,000 per violation for health care entities. The amendment to Section 425 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 includes provisions for reporting adverse actions to State licensing boards and imposing civil penalties of up to $50,000 per violation for health care entities or agencies employing physicians or other licensed health care practitioners who fail to comply with the regulations. The amendment to Section 425 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 allows for civil penalties of up to $50,000 per violation for health care entities or agencies with repeated violations. SEC. 5. PROFESSIONAL REVIEW. Section 411 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 provides civil liability immunity for health care entities that disclose information about current or former employees, unless false information is knowingly disclosed or the employee's rights are violated. This immunity applies to authorized individuals providing information in accordance with the Act. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 provides civil liability immunity for health care entities that disclose information about employees. A health care entity cannot penalize an employee for reporting conduct that may violate laws to a State authority or employer. SEC. 6 amends the Health Care Quality Improvement Act to include skilled nursing facilities. SEC. 7 addresses sanctions and background checks for health care practitioners and providers. Section 1921 of the Social Security Act is amended to include criminal background checks for licensed health care practitioners. The State must report this information to the designated agency under the Health Care Quality Improvement Act. The date of implementation is specified in Section 8. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement the provisions of the Act within 1 year of its enactment.
